Share your website with the world (2) - FileZilla Version

items.description: In this lecture, you will learn the syntax of HTML headings and add different headings to your website.
items.title: Headings

items.description: In this lecture, you will learn the syntax of HTML paragraphs, you will create your first paragraph. You will then create your second paragraph and add a line break inside it.
items.title: Paragraphs

items.description: In this lecture, you will add links to your website. This session will cover different types of links, links taking you to an external website, links taking you to a file in the same server you are working in and links taking you to a certain HTML element in your website itself.
items.title: Links

items.description: In this video, you will add images to your website. This section will cover images located in your server as well as external images living in other servers. Also you will add basic styling to pictures using basic attributes like the width and height.
items.title: Images

items.description: In this lecture, you will understand the difference in behaviour between the main two types of HTML elements: Inline Elements and Block Elements
items.title: Inline vs Block Elements

items.description: In this lecture, you will embed external websites inside your website using Iframes, also you will add a nice relaxing YouTube video to your website.
items.title: Iframes - Activity: Embed a nice relaxing YouTube video to your website

items.description: In this lecture, you will create your first unordered list, and also add a nice sub-list inside your unordered list.
items.title: Unordered Lists

items.description: In this lecture, you will create a few types of ordered lists
items.title: Ordered Lists

items.description: In this lecture, you will create a description/definition list defining two main Web Technologies in this course: HTML and CSS.
items.title: Description Lists

items.description: In this lecture, you will create a simple HTML table consisting of three columns: Name, Company and Data of Birth, then you will populate it using details of famous people like Mark Zuckerberg or Steve Jobs.
items.title: Tables

items.description: In this lecture, you will create HTML entities like the copyright symbol or the less than sign.
items.title: Entities

items.description: In this lecture, you will create a simple login form using HTML text inputs and password inputs. You will add labels inside your form. And you will add a Login button to submit you form. I will briefly mention the different types of forms (get and post) that we will cover later in the PHP chapter.
items.title: Forms (1) - Activity: Create a simple Login Form

items.description: In this lecture, you will create a nice Marketplace Checkout Form, it will consist of fields like the customer address, their preferred shipping method, payment method, etc. You will use new input types like checkboxes and radio buttons which I will explain in detail.
items.title: Forms (2) - Activity: Create a Marketplace Checkout Form

items.description: In this lecture, you will style text using basic HTML tags. (Advanced styling using CSS will be covered in the next chapter).
items.title: Text Decoration

items.description: In this lecture, you will add comments to HTML code to make your code more readable.
items.title: Comments

sections.title: Introduction - Get your free Unlimited Web Hosting - HTML

items.description: In this lecture you will get introduced to CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) which you will use later to style and decorate your websites.
items.title: Introduction

items.description: Please make sure you download this file before you move to the next lectures of this chapter. It will show you the structure of the current chapter and provide you with the necessary source code that will make your learning experience easier
items.title: CSS Chapter: Roadmap and Full Source Code

items.description: In this lecture, you will learn how to style HTML elements using inline styling, which uses the style attribute that goes inside the element tag. In the first example you will set the font-size and color of a paragraph.
items.title: Inline CSS

items.description: In this lecture, you will learn how to style HTML elements using internal CSS which goes inside the head section of the website. You will learn how to select elements you would like to style and add styling to them.
items.title: Internal CSS

items.description: In this lecture, you will learn how to use external CSS to styling HTML elements. You will style your website this time using and external file that you will link to your website using the link element inside the head of your website.
items.title: External CSS

items.description: In this lecture, you will get introduced to the class and id concepts, which you will use to style different HTML elements with minimal code.
items.title: Classes and IDs

items.description: In this lecture, you will get introduced to the Div and Span concepts and use them to add styling to your website.
items.title: Div and Span

items.description: In this lecture, you will get introduced to the box model, which you will use in the next few lectures to add padding, borders and margins to HTML elements.
items.title: Box Model

items.description: In this lecture, you will learn the padding concept and its syntax. You will add padding to div elements in your page.
items.title: Box Model: Padding

items.description: In this lecture, you will learn the border concept and its syntax. You will add borders to div elements in your page.
items.title: Box Model: Border

items.description: In this lecture, you will learn the outline concept and its syntax. You will add outlines to div elements in your page.
items.title: Box Model: Outline

items.description: In this lecture, you will learn the margin concept and its syntax. You will add margins to div elements in your page.
items.title: Box Model: Margin

items.description: In this lecture, you will get introduced to the background CSS properties and use them to style HTML elements using background images.
items.title: Background

items.description: In this lecture, you will use the CSS float property to control how HTML elements float on a webpage.
items.title: Floating

items.description: In this lecture, you will learn different types of CSS positioning: fixed, relative and absolute positioning. You will use them to position HTML elements on your webpage. You will also use the z-index property to decide which element show on top of the other if two HTML elements overlap.
items.title: Positioning

items.description: In this lecture, you will learn how to use the CSS properties: display and visibility to hide or show HTML elements. You will also learn the difference between these two properties.
items.title: Display

items.description: In this lecture, you will use how to use CSS properties (text-decoration, font-weight, etc.) to decorate text, i.e. underlining text, make text bold, adding text shadow, etc.
items.title: Text Decoration

items.description: In this lecture, you will learn how to use CSS properties to align text just like you would do on a text editor like Microsoft word.
items.title: Text Align

items.description: In this lecture, you will learn how to set text font family. You will also learn the difference between generic and specific families.
items.title: Text Font

items.description: In this lecture, you will use CSS properties to control the behaviour of text overflowing of an HTML element by breaking it, wrapping it or hiding it.
items.title: Text Effects

items.description: In this lecture, you will use image sprites to use only a part of an image in your webpage rather than the full picture.
items.title: Image Sprites

items.description: In this lecture, you will learn how to add opacity to HTML pictures and control how transparent they are.
items.title: Image Opacity

items.description: In this lecture, you will style two lists of European capitals using the CSS list properties.
items.title: Styling Lists

items.description: In this lecture, you will style HTML links in different states: standard, active, visited.
items.title: Styling Links

items.description: In this lecture, you will style a div using gradients
items.title: Gradients

items.description: In this lecture, you will apply 2D transforms to an HTML div: rotation, translation, skewing
items.title: 2D Transforms

items.description: In this lecture, you will apply 3D transforms to an HTML div: 3D rotation
items.title: 3D Transforms

items.description: In this lecture, you will add nice transitions to HTML elements: you will make them change their dimensions and apply 2D or 3D transforms for a specific duration.
items.title: Transitions

items.description: In this lecture, you will create nice animations on your webpage using the CSS animation property. We will animate a div by moving it following a nice rectangular route and changing its colour on the way.
items.title: Animations

items.description: In this lecture, you will get introduced to JavaScript and the different powerful features it adds to your websites. You will create a nice webpage with an alert message showing up on page load.
items.title: Introduction

items.description: Please make sure you download this file before you move to the next lectures of this chapter. It will show you the structure of the current chapter and provide you with the necessary source code that will make your learning experience easier
items.title: JavaScript Chapter: Roadmap and Full Source Code

items.description: In this lecture, we will create two buttons and write JavaScript code that responds to clicking on the buttons. For the first button we will write code inside the button tag. For the second one we will write code inside the script element.
items.title: Buttons

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn how to change HTML content following an event like clicking or double clicking on a button.
items.title: Change HTML Content

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn how to change HTML Style like font-size or font-family following an event like clicking or double clicking on a button.
items.title: Change HTML Style

items.description: In this lecture, we will use get introduced to variables which are simple containers which store data like a number or string. We will also get introduced to the different types of variables.
items.title: Variables and Data Types

items.description: In this lecture, we will change HTML content using variables. This time we will apply our skills to create a random color generator that will affect a random new color to a div whenever we click on a button.
items.title: Change HTML Using Variables - Activity: Random Color Generator

items.description: In this lecture, we will get introduced to the function concept which will save a lot while coding. We will use our knowledge to create a function that will swap the content of two divs whenever we click on a button.
items.title: Functions: Activity: Swap the content of two divs

items.description: In this lecture, we will dive into some JavaScript object oriented concepts: We will get introduced to objects and create our first object using a simple syntax.
items.title: Objects

items.description: This time we will create an object using the new key word.
items.title: Create Objects using the "new" keyword

items.description: This time we will create an object using another way: we will use a constructor which is a function we will define first which shows the different properties and methods of a prototype, then we will use this function to construct objects.
items.title: Object Contructors

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn arrays which will help store multiple variables inside one variable: the array.
items.title: Arrays

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn the â€œif and switch statements â€œwhich will tell the browser to do certain things based on certain conditions. We will use our knowledge to build a motorway speed control telling us if we are over speeding, going too slow or driving at a good speed based on our speedometer!
items.title: If and Switch Statements - Activity: Motorway Speed Control

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn for loops, which will help us execute the same piece of code over and over without having to repeat the code at all.
items.title: For Loops

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn while loops, which will help us execute the same piece of code over and over while a certain condition is true. We will use our knowledge to build an application spending randomly 1000$ in marketplace, we will be spending and spending while the condition â€œwe still have moneyâ€ is true!
items.title: While Loops - Activity: Spend $1000 Randomly in a marketplace

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn regular expressions which are usually used to check a certain user input against a certain criteria like including at least one digit.
items.title: Regular Expressions

items.description: In this lecture, we will show JavaScript errors to our user in a user friendly way.
items.title: Errors (1)

items.description: We will apply our skills to create a password validation example where we require the password to include at least 6 characters, one number and one capital letter. If there is an error, we show the user a user friendly message on the screen.
items.title: Errors (2) - Activity: Password Validation

items.description: In this lecture, we will get introduced to timing function like setInterval which will execute the same piece of code each time a specified number of milliseconds has elapsed. We will use this function to create a counter.
items.title: Set Interval & SeTimeout - Activity: Create a simple counter

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn how to access the with and height properties of the user browser or device screen. We will use our knowledge to build a webpage with 4 equal colourful divs.
items.title: Window and Screen

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn confirmation boxes which are used to make the user accept or refuse a certain action. We also cover prompt boxes which ask the user some information like their name for example.
items.title: Alert Boxes

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn how to set cookies using JavaScript. (We will also cover cookies later in the PHP chapter)
items.title: Cookies

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn how to use jQuery syntax to select HTML elements using their HTML tag, id, class, etc.

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn how to use jQuery syntax to select HTML elements using their HTML tag, id, class, etc.
items.title: Select HTML Elements (2)

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn how to use jQuery to respond to events like clicking on a button or hover on an element.
items.title: Respond to Events

items.description: In this lecture we will learn how to use jQuery to change HTML elements content and attributes
items.title: Change HTML Content and Attributes (1)

items.description: In this lecture we will learn how to use jQuery to change HTML Styling: we will learn how to change properties like the width of an element. Also we will learn how to add a class or remove a class.
items.title: Change Styling (1)

items.description: We will apply our skills to create a random position and color generator: Our application will make a div reposition itself randomly and get a new random color every time it is clicked.
items.title: Change Styling (2) - Activity: Random Position and Color Generator

items.description: In this lecture, we learn how to add jQuery effects like fading out or fading in elements, creating animations with a specified duration or creating a delay before a certain action takes place.
items.title: JQuery Effects

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn Ajax and use it to exchange data between our website and external resources, and update our page with received data without reloading the page.
items.title: Ajax

items.description: In this lecture, we will get introduced to jQuery UI and the different powerful features it offers for web developers.
items.title: JQuery UI Introduction

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn how to make HTML elements draggable. We will apply our knowledge by creating a funny draggable box which will get random colours continuously while being dragged and also display text like â€œdrop meâ€ or â€œleave me aloneâ€. Once it is dropped it goes back to its original location and displays: â€œFinallyâ€
items.title: Draggable and Droppable (1) - Activity: Leave me alone! Please drop me!

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn how to make a certain element droppable. We will apply our knowledge to drag items to a box and copy a clone of these items inside our box.
items.title: Draggable and Droppable (2) - Activity: Drag Items to your basket

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn how to make elements resizable using jQuery UI.
items.title: Resizable

items.description: In this   lecture, we will learn how to make elements selectable using jQuery UI. We   will apply our skills by create an application where once we select one or   multiple selectable Car Makes, they get appended to a box.
items.title: Selectable - Activity: Append selected Car Makes to a Box

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn how to make list elements sortable. We will apply our knowledge by creating two lists of sortable Car Makes that we can sort and exchange using drag and drop.
items.title: Sortable - Activity: Sort and exchange Car Makes between two groups

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn how to create accordions using jQuery UI. We will apply our knowledge to create a resizable accordion with collapsible sections.
items.title: Accordion - Activity: Create a resizable accordion with collapsible sections

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn how to create inputs with prepopulated data using jQuery UI.
items.title: Autocomplete - Activity: City Input with prepopulated options

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn how to create and style buttons and checkboxes, add icons â€¦ using jQuery UI.
items.title: Button

items.description: In this lecture, we will use the date picker feature of jQuery UI, to create data inputs helping the user with a calendar. We will then practise our knowledge by creating an Outbound and return Flight Date Picker just like Expedia.com. We will write code to make sure that our return flight date is after our Outbound flight date.
items.title: Date Picker - Activity: Outbound and return Flight Date Picker just like Expedia

items.description: In this lecture, we will learn the dialog feature of jQuery UI. We will apply our knowledge by creating a nice dialog box, asking us if we want to go the previous page or cancel.
items.title: Dialog - Activity: Are you sure you want to go to the previous page?

items.description: In this lecture, we will create a nice styled menu using jQuery UI. We will create another menu with headers in it.
items.title: Menu

items.description: In this lecture, we will get introduced to jQuery UI progress bar feature, and we will use our knowledge to build a nice Animated progress bar filled from 0% to 100%.
items.title: Progress Bar - Activity: Animated progress bar filled from 0% to 100%

items.description: In this lecture, we learn jQuery UI select menus. We will create one styled menu, and another menu with headers in it.
items.title: Select Menu

items.description: In this lecture, we learn jQuery UI sliders. We will apply our skills by create a slider that we can use to select a car mileage range with a step of 1000 miles ranging from 0 to 100000 miles.
items.title: Slider - Activity: Car Mileage Range using a Slider

Easy to learn

Become a Python Programmer and learn one of employer's most requested skills of 2022!


This is the most comprehensive, yet straight-forward, course for the Python programming language on Udemy! Whether you have never programmed before, already know basic syntax, or want to learn about the advanced features of Python, this course is for you! In this course we willÂ teach you Python 3.

With over 100 lectures and more than 21 hours of video this comprehensive course leaves no stone unturned! This course includes quizzes, tests, coding exercises and homework assignments as well as 3 major projects to create a Python project portfolio!

Learn how to use Python for real-world tasks, such as working with PDF Files, sending emails, reading Excel files, Scraping websites for informations, working with image files, and much more!

This course will teach you Python in a practical manner, with every lecture comes a full coding screencast and a corresponding code notebook! Learn in whatever manner is best for you!

We will start by helping you get Python installed on your computer, regardless of your operating system, whether its Linux, MacOS, or Windows, we've got you covered.

We cover a wide variety of topics, including:

Command Line Basics

args/kwargs

items.description: Meet your instructor, and we'll review what this course will cover and what you need to get started.
items.title: Introduction

items.description: How to find the scripts and data associated with the lectures in this course.
items.title: How to Use This Course
Udemy 101: Getting the Most From This Course
IMPORTANT! DO NOT USE JAVA 16 WITH THIS COURSE

items.description: We'll install Anaconda, a JDK, and Apache Spark on your Windows system. When we're done, we'll run a simple little Spark script on your desktop to test it out!
items.title: [Activity]Getting Set Up: Installing Python, a JDK, Spark, and its Dependencies.

items.description: Before we can analyze data with Spark, we need some data to analyze! Let's install the MovieLens dataset of movie ratings, which we'll use throughout the course.
items.title: [Activity] Installing the MovieLens Movie Rating Dataset

items.description: We'll run a simple Spark script using Python, and analyze the 1000 movie ratings you installed in the previous lecture. What is the breakdown of the rating scores in this data set? You'll find it's easy to find out!
items.title: [Activity] Run your first Spark program! Ratings histogram example.

items.description: Apache Spark 3 was released in early 2020 - here's what's new, what's improved, and what's deprecated.
items.title: What's new in Spark 3?

items.description: This high-level introduction will help you understand what Spark is for, who's using it, and why it's such a big deal.
items.title: Introduction to Spark

items.description: Understand the core object of Spark: the Resilient Distributed Dataset (RDD), and how you can use Spark to transform and perform actions upon RDD's.
items.title: The Resilient Distributed Dataset (RDD)

items.description: We'll dissect our original ratings histogram Spark example, and understand exactly how every line of it works!
items.title: Ratings Histogram Walkthrough

items.description: You'll learn how to use key/value pairs in RDD's, and special operations you can perform on them. To make it real, we'll introduce a new example: computing the average number of friends by age using a fake social network data set.
items.title: Key/Value RDD's, and the Average Friends by Age Example

items.description: We'll take another look at our "average number of friends by age" example script, actually run it, and examine the results.
items.title: [Activity] Running the Average Friends by Age Example

items.description: Learn how the filter() operation works on RDD's, and apply this toward finding the minimum temperatures from a real-world weather data set.
items.title: Filtering RDD's, and the Minimum Temperature by Location Example

items.description: We'll look at the minimum temperatures by location example as a whole, and actually run it! Then, you've got an activity: modify this script to find the maximum temperatures instead. This lecture reinforces using filters and key/value RDD's.
items.title: [Activity]Running the Minimum Temperature Example, and Modifying it for Maximums

items.description: Check your results for writing a maximum temperature Spark script to my own.
items.title: [Activity] Running the Maximum Temperature by Location Example

items.description: We'll do the standard "count the number of occurrences of each word in a book" exercise here, and review the differences between map() and flatmap() in the process.
items.title: [Activity] Counting Word Occurrences using flatmap()

items.description: You'll learn how to use regular expressions in Python, and use them to improve the results of our word count script.
items.title: [Activity] Improving the Word Count Script with Regular Expressions

items.description: Finally, we'll learn how to implement countByValue() in a way that returns a new RDD, and sort that RDD to produce our final results for word frequency.
items.title: [Activity] Sorting the Word Count Results

items.description: Write your first Spark script on your own! I'll give you the strategy and tips you need to be successful. You're given a fake e-commerce data set, and your task is to find the total amount spent, broken down by customer ID.
items.title: [Exercise] Find the Total Amount Spent by Customer

items.description: Compare your code to my solution for finding the total spent by customer - and take on a new challenge! Modify your script to sort your final results by the amount spent, and find the biggest spender.
items.title: [Excercise] Check your Results, and Now Sort them by Total Amount Spent.

items.description: Compare your solution to sorting the customers by total amount ordered to mine, and check your results.
items.title: Check Your Sorted Implementation and Results Against Mine.

sections.title: Spark Basics and the RDD Interface

items.description: We'll cover the concepts of SparkSQL, DataFrames, and DataSets, and why they are so important in Spark 2.0 and above.
items.title: Introducing SparkSQL

items.description: We'll dive into a real example, revisiting our fake social network data and analyzing it with DataFrames through a SparkSession object.
items.title: [Activity] Executing SQL commands and SQL-style functions on a DataFrame

items.description: Let's revisit our "most popular movie" example, and implement it using a DataFrame instead of withÂ RDD's. DataFrames are the preferred API in Spark 2.0+.
items.title: Using DataFrames instead of RDD's
Exercise Solution: Friends by Age, with DataFrames
[Activity] Minimum Temperature, with DataFrames (using a custom schema)
[Exercise] Implement Total Spent by Customer with DataFrames
Exercise Solution: Total Spent by Customer, with DataFrames

items.description: We'll write and run a simple script to find the most-rated movie in the MovieLens data set, which we'll build upon later.
items.title: [Activity] Find the Most Popular Movie

items.description: You'll learn how to use "broadcast variables" in Spark to efficiently distribute large objects to every node your Spark program may be running on, and apply this to looking up movie names in our "most popular movie" script.
items.title: [Activity] Use Broadcast Variables to Display Movie Names Instead of ID Numbers

items.description: We introduce the Marvel superhero social graph data set, and write a Spark job to find the superhero with the most co-occurrences with other heroes in comic books.
items.title: Find the Most Popular Superhero in a Social Graph

items.description: Review the source code of our script to discover the most popular superhero, run it, and reveal the answer!
items.title: [Activity] Run the Script - Discover Who the Most Popular Superhero is!

items.description: We'll introduce the Breadth-First Search (BFS) algorithm, and how we can use it to discover degrees of separation between superheroes.
items.title: Superhero Degrees of Separation: Introducing Breadth-First Search

items.description: We'll learn how to turn breadth-first search into a Spark problem, and craft our strategy for writing the code. Along the way, we'll cover Spark accumulators and how we can use them to signal our driver script when it's done.
items.title: Superhero Degrees of Separation:  Accumulators, and Implementing BFS in Spark

items.description: We'll get our hands on the code to actually implement breadth-first search, and run it to discover the degrees of separation between any two superheroes!
items.title: [Activity] Superhero Degrees of Separation: Review the Code and Run it

items.description: Learn one technique for finding similar movies based on the MovieLens rating data, and how we can frame it as a Spark problem. We'll also introduce the importance of using cache() or persist() on rdd's that will have more than one action performed on them.
items.title: Item-Based Collaborative Filtering in Spark, cache(), and persist()

items.description: We'll review the code for finding similar movies in Spark with the MovieLens ratings data, run it on every available core of your desktop computer, and review the results.
items.title: [Activity] Running the Similar Movies Script using Spark's Cluster Manager

items.description: Get your hands dirty! I'll give you some ideas on improving the quality of your similar movie results - go try some out, and mess around with our movie similarity code.
items.title: [Exercise] Improve the Quality of Similar Movies

items.description: Learn how Amazon's Elastic MapReduce makes it easy to rent time on your very own Spark cluster, running on top of Hadoop YARN
items.title: Introducing Elastic MapReduce

items.description: Learn how to set up your AWS account, create a key pair for logging into your Spark / Hadoop cluster, and set up PuTTY to connect to your instances from a Windows desktop.
items.title: [Activity] Setting up your AWS / Elastic MapReduce Account and Setting Up PuTTY

items.description: We'll see what needs to be done to our Movie Similarities script in order to get it to run successfully with one million ratings, on a cluster, by introducing the partitionBy() function.
items.title: Partitioning

items.description: We'll study the code of our modified movie similarities script, and get it ready to run on a cluster.
items.title: Create Similar Movies from One Million Ratings - Part 1

items.description: We'll launch a Hadoop cluster with Spark using Amazon's Elastic MapReduce service, and kick off our script to produce similar movies to Star Wars given one million movie ratings.
items.title: [Activity] Create Similar Movies from One Million Ratings - Part 2

items.description: We'll look at our results from similar movies from one million ratings, and discuss them.
items.title: Create Similar Movies from One Million Ratings - Part 3

items.description: We'll look at the Spark console UI and the information it offers to help understand how to diagnose problems and optimize your large Spark jobs.
items.title: Troubleshooting Spark on a Cluster

items.description: I'll share some more troubleshooting tips when running Spark on a cluster, and talk about how to manage dependencies your code may have.
items.title: More Troubleshooting, and Managing Dependencies

items.description: We'll briefly cover the capabilities of Spark's MLLib machine learning library, and how it can help you solve data mining, machine learning, and statistical problems you may encounter. We'll go into more depth on MLLib's Alternating Least Squares (ALS) recommendation engine, and how we can use it to produce movie recommendations with the MovieLens data set.
items.title: Introducing MLLib

items.description: We'll run MLLib's Alternating Least Squares recommender system on the MovieLens 100K dataset.
items.title: [Activity] Using Spark ML to Produce Movie Recommendations

items.description: We'll finish running Alternating Least Squares recommendations on the MovieLens ratings data set using MLLib, and evaluate the results.
items.title: Analyzing the ALS Recommendations Results

items.description: DataFrames are the preferred API for MLLib in Spark 2.0+. Let's look at an example of using linear regression withÂ DataFrames.
items.title: [Activity] Linear Regression with Spark ML
[Exercise] Using Decision Trees in Spark ML to Predict Real Estate Prices
Exercise Solution: Decision Trees with Spark

items.description: An overview of how Spark Streaming lets you process continual streams on input data and aggregate it over time, and how GraphX lets you compute properties of networks.
items.title: Spark Streaming

items.description: We'll run an example of Spark structured streaming in Python to keep track of status code counts in a directory that receives Apache access logs.
items.title: [Activity] Structured Streaming in Python
[Exercise] Use Windows with Structured Streaming to Track Most-Viewed URL's
Exercise Solution: Using Structured Streaming with Windows

items.description: GraphX isn't currently supported in Python, but you should at least know what it is.
items.title: GraphX

sections.title: Spark Streaming, Structured Streaming, and GraphX

items.description: Some suggested resources for learning more about Apache Spark, and data mining and machine learning in general.
items.title: learning More about Spark and Data Science
Bonus Lecture: More courses to explore!

sections.title: You Made It! Where to Go from Here.

Requirements: Access to a personal computer. This course uses Windows, but the sample code will work fine on Linux as well.
Some prior programming or scripting experience. Python experience will help a lot, but you can pick it up as we go.
details.description:
New!Â Updated forÂ Spark 3, more hands-on exercises, and a stronger focus on DataFrames and Structured Streaming.

â€œBig data" analysis is a hot and highly valuable skill â€“ and this course will teach you the hottest technology in big data: Apache Spark and specifically PySpark. Employers including Amazon, EBay, NASA JPL, and Yahoo all use Spark to quickly extract meaning from massive data sets across a fault-tolerant Hadoop cluster. You'll learn those same techniques, using your own Windows system right at home. It's easier than you might think.

Learn and master the art of framing data analysis problems as Spark problems through over 20 hands-on examples, and then scale them up to run on cloud computing services in this course. You'll be learning from an ex-engineer and senior manager fromÂ Amazon and IMDb.




Learn the concepts of Spark's DataFrames and Resilient Distributed Datastores

Develop and run Spark jobs quickly using Python and pyspark

Translate complex analysis problems into iterative or multi-stage Spark scripts

Scale up to larger data sets using Amazon's Elastic MapReduce service

Understand how Hadoop YARN distributes Spark across computing clusters

Learn about other Spark technologies, like Spark SQL, Spark Streaming, and GraphX

By the end of this course, you'll be running code that analyzes gigabytes worth of information â€“ in the cloud â€“ in a matter of minutes.Â 

This course uses the familiar Python programming language; if you'd rather use Scala to get the best performance out of Spark, see my "ApacheÂ Spark withÂ Scala - Hands On withÂ BigÂ Data" course instead.


We'll have some fun along the way. You'll get warmed up with some simple examples of using Spark to analyze movie ratings data and text in a book. Once you've got the basics under your belt, we'll move to some more complex and interesting tasks. We'll use a million movie ratings to find movies that are similar to each other, and you might even discover some new movies you might like in the process! We'll analyze a social graph of superheroes, and learn who the most â€œpopular" superhero is â€“ and develop a system to find â€œdegrees of separation" between superheroes. Are all Marvel superheroes within a few degrees of being connected to The Incredible Hulk? You'll find the answer.

This course is very hands-on; you'll spend most of your time following along with the instructor as we write, analyze, and run real code together â€“ both on your own system, and in the cloud using Amazon's Elastic MapReduce service. 7 hours of video content is included, with over 20 real examples of increasing complexity you can build, run and study yourself. Move through them at your own pace, on your own schedule. The course wraps up with an overview of other Spark-based technologies, including Spark SQL, Spark Streaming, and GraphX.

Wrangling big data with ApacheÂ Spark is an important skill in today's technical world. Enroll now!




" I studied "Taming Big Data with Apache Spark and Python" with Frank Kane, and helped me build a great platform for Big Data as a Service for my company. I recommend the course!Â  " - Cleuton Sampaio De Melo Jr.
details.for_who:
People with some software development background who want to learn the hottest technology in big data analysis will want to check this out. This course focuses on Spark from a software development standpoint; we introduce some machine learning and data mining concepts along the way, but that's not the focus. If you want to learn how to use Spark to carve up huge datasets and extract meaning from them, then this course is for you.
If you've never written a computer program or a script before, this course isn't for you - yet. I suggest starting with a Python course first, if programming is new to you.
If your software development job involves, or will involve, processing large amounts of data, you need to know about Spark.
If you're training for a new career in data science or big data, Spark is an important part of it.

items.title: Thank you for enrolling in my course!

Requirements: Students will need a computer, tablet, or smart phone, and an internet connection.
Materials required: Drawing paper, and a pencil, crayon, or marker.
Bring it: A desire to create some nifty drawings!
details.description:
Do you know a budding artist who is interested in learning how to draw?

Are you looking for an experienced art teacher to guide them throughout the creative process?

Are you seeking aÂ healthyÂ activity that will encourageÂ creativity and boost self-confidence?Â 

This Beginner's Drawing Course may be just what you are looking for! Designed with young artists in mind, this drawing course is suitable for ALLÂ AGES. The teaching process used is a step-by-step method that will inspire and delight students into drawing action! The process involves organizing shapes and lines together until a recognizable outcome is achieved. Beginner artists may then apply the knowledge they gain through each lesson to create unique masterpieces of their own. This Beginner's Drawing Course is designed to give new artists the tools they need to begin their artistic journey into self-expression, reflection, and creative thinking.

Please Note: This course is intended to be purchased by a parent or guardian for use by a beginner artist or novice art student. Adult supervision is recommended. Per Udemyâ€™s Policy: Those under 18 may use the services only if a parent or guardian opens their account, handles any enrollments, and manages their account usage.

I would love to hear from you.

Please let me know if you have questions, comments, or suggestions. I am here to help :)

About the Instructor:

My name is Miss Em and teaching art to children is what I love to do! I pride myself on creating dynamic, meaningful, and engaging art lessons that are taught in a relaxing and joyful way. I have over 20 years teaching experience in the elementary classroom and in the art studio, and I feel that I have a good grasp on how to create an environment that makes kids feel happy, motivated, confident, and successful.

I look forward to seeing you in this Beginner's Drawing Course.

Let the creative fun begin!
details.for_who:
This is a beginning drawing course designed for beginners and young artists.
No drawing experience necessary.

Requirements: A basic understanding of Javascript
details.description:
In only seven hours you will learn enough JavaScript to transform from a junior javascript developer into a senior javascript guru.


You will dramatically improve your chances of getting past a technical interview, landing that dream job and earning more money.

If you are like me you learnt Javascript by just muddling along, seeing what works and learning a thing or two every day.

However, without a grasp of the deeper fundamentals, you will hit quite a few head scratchy issues, introduce bugs, find it hard to read and understand framework and library code and wonâ€™t be considered a senior developer.

This unique course teaches you advanced javascript knowledge through a series of interview questions, with regular quizzes on the way through to cement your knowledge.

What are you going to learn?

Types & Equality: The different types in JS and how to check if two values are really equal?

Scopes: The different scopes a variable can be declared in and how to manipulate those scopes.

DestructuringÂ  & Looping:Â Did you know that JavaScript has for methods of looping over things?

This:Â We have a whole section dedicated to the this keyword. A deep understanding of the this keyword is core to becoming a senior JavaScript developer.

Object Orientation: The history of OOÂ in JavaScript from the Prototype Pattern to the Pseudo-Classical/Constructor Pattern all the way to the class syntax introduced in ES6. You need to know the previous patterns to truly understand the current class pattern.

Asynchronous Programming:Â JavaScript power is in its asynchronicity, you will learn all about the pros and cons of callbacks, promises and async/await.

Advanced topics in Networking such as CORS and JSONP.

Advanced topics in Event Handling such as the different event phases.

Why an interview format?


I find that it's only when I'm facing an upcoming interview that I get into gear and really make sure I have a deep understanding of what I claim to know.

I might know the best practice for how to solve a problem, but do I know why?

Javascript interviews are designed to dig deeper into your knowledge of a subject, see if you are just mimicking what you have read or if you have a proper understanding.

Also, it's FUN, what's more satisfying than learning something, then passing a test!
details.for_who:
Maybe your a JS developer looking to change jobs and isnâ€™t looking forward to the interview, I mean who does?
Maybe itâ€™s been a while since you wrote JS and you want to get a refresher on the latest features.
Maybe you just finished another Beginner or Intermediate JavaScript course and want to get to the next level
Just about to enter the job market after a career change
New graduates coming out of university

details.description:
Do you know a young artist who would enjoy learning how to draw and paint with watercolor paints?

Are you looking for an experienced art teacher to guide them throughout the creative process?

Are you seeking aÂ healthyÂ activity that will encourageÂ creativity and boost self-confidence?Â 

This Drawing and Watercolor Painting course may be just what you are looking for!Â Designed with beginners in mind, this course is suitable for ALLÂ AGES. With a total of 15 uniqueÂ drawing and watercolor paintingÂ projects, students will learn the skills to create masterpieces of their own long after the course is complete.

The teaching process used for the drawing portion of eachÂ project is a step-by-step method that will inspire and delight students into drawing action! This process involves organizing shapes and lines together until a recognizable outcome is achieved.

After students complete the drawing portion of their project, they will move onto painting the project. Young artists will learn basic watercolor techniques and apply these techniques to complete their project. ThisÂ Drawing and WatercolorÂ Painting course is designed to give beginners the tools they need to begin their artistic journey into self-expression, reflection, and creative thinking.

Supplies and materials needed for this course:

watercolor paper

watercolor paints

paintbrushes

crayons or oil pastels

paper towels

bowl of water

mat to protect work area

items.description: What to expect in this course, who it's for, and the general format we'll follow.
items.title: Introduction
Udemy 101: Getting the Most From This Course
[Activity] WINDOWS: Installing and Using Anaconda & Course Materials
[Activity] MAC: Installing and Using Anaconda  & Course Materials
[Activity] LINUX: Installing and Using Anaconda  & Course Materials

items.description: In a crash course on Python and what's different about it, we'll cover the importance of whitespace in Python scripts, and how to import Python modules.
items.title: Python Basics, Part 1 [Optional]

items.description: In part 2 of our Python crash course, we'll cover Python data structures including lists, tuples, and dictionaries.
items.title: [Activity] Python Basics, Part 2 [Optional]

items.description: In this lesson, we'll see how functions work in Python.
items.title: [Activity] Python Basics, Part 3 [Optional]

items.description: We'll wrap up our Python crash course covering Boolean expressions and looping constructs.
items.title: [Activity] Python Basics, Part 4 [Optional]

items.description: Pandas is a library we'll use throughout the course for loading, examining, and manipulating data. Let's see how it works with some examples, and you'll have an exercise at the end too.
items.title: Introducing the Pandas Library [Optional]

items.description: We cover the differences between continuous and discrete numerical data, categorical data, and ordinal data.
items.title: Types of Data (Numerical, Categorical, Ordinal)

items.description: A refresher on mean, median, and mode - and when it's appropriate to use each.
items.title: Mean, Median, Mode

items.description: We'll use mean, median, and mode in some real Python code, and set you loose to write some code of your own.
items.title: [Activity] Using mean, median, and mode in Python

items.description: We'll cover how to compute the variation and standard deviation of a data distribution, and how to do it using some examples in Python.
items.title: [Activity] Variation and Standard Deviation

items.description: Introducing the concepts of probability density functions (PDF's) and probability mass functions (PMF's).
items.title: Probability Density Function; Probability Mass Function

items.description: We'll show examples of continuous, normal, exponential, binomial, and poisson distributions using iPython.
items.title: Common Data Distributions (Normal, Binomial, Poisson, etc)

items.description: We'll look at some examples of percentiles and quartiles in data distributions, and then move on to the concept of the first four moments of data sets.
items.title: [Activity] Percentiles and Moments

items.description: An overview of different tricks in matplotlib for creating graphs of your data, using different graph types and styles.
items.title: [Activity] A Crash Course in matplotlib

items.description: The concepts of covariance and correlation used to look for relationships between different sets of attributes, and some examples in Python.
items.title: [Activity] Covariance and Correlation

items.description: We cover the concepts and equations behind conditional probability, and use it to try and find a relationship between age and purchases in some fabricated data using Python.
items.title: [Exercise] Conditional Probability

items.description: Here we'll go over my solution to the exercise I challenged you with in the previous lecture - changing our fabricated data to have no real correlation between ages and purchases, and seeing if you can detect that using conditional probability.
items.title: Exercise Solution: Conditional Probability of Purchase by Age

items.description: An overview of Bayes' Theorem, and an example of using it to uncover misleading statistics surrounding the accuracy of drug testing.
items.title: Bayes' Theorem

sections.title: Statistics and Probability Refresher, and Python Practice

items.description: We introduce the concept of linear regression and how it works, and use it to fit a line to some sample data using Python.
items.title: [Activity] Linear Regression

items.description: We cover the concepts of polynomial regression, and use it to fit a more complex page speed - purchase relationship in Python.
items.title: [Activity] Polynomial Regression

items.description: Multivariate models let us predict some value given more than one attribute. We cover the concept, then use it to build a model in Python to predict car prices based on their number of doors, mileage, and number of cylinders. We'll also get our first look at the statsmodels library in Python.
items.title: [Activity] Multiple Regression, and Predicting Car Prices

items.description: We'll just cover the concept of multi-level modeling, as it is a very advanced topic. But you'll get the ideas and challenges behind it.
items.title: Multi-Level Models

items.description: The concepts of supervised and unsupervised machine learning, and how to evaluate the ability of a machine learning model to predict new values using the train/test technique.
items.title: Supervised vs. Unsupervised Learning, and Train/Test

items.description: We'll apply train test to a real example using Python.
items.title: [Activity] Using Train/Test to Prevent Overfitting a Polynomial Regression

items.description: We'll introduce the concept of Naive Bayes and how we might apply it to the problem of building a spam classifier.
items.title: Bayesian Methods: Concepts

items.description: We'll actually write a working spam classifier, using real email training data and a surprisingly small amount of code!
items.title: [Activity] Implementing a Spam Classifier with  Naive Bayes

items.description: K-Means is a way to identify things that are similar to each other. It's a case of unsupervised learning, which could result in clusters you never expected!
items.title: K-Means Clustering

items.description: We'll apply K-Means clustering to find interesting groupings of people based on their age and income.
items.title: [Activity] Clustering people based on income and age

items.description: Entropy is a measure of the disorder in a data set - we'll learn what that means, and how to compute it mathematically.
items.title: Measuring Entropy

items.description: Decision trees can automatically create a flow chart for making some decision, based on machine learning! Let's learn how they work.
items.title: Decision Trees: Concepts

items.description: We'll create a decision tree and an entire "random forest" to predict hiring decisions for job candidates.
items.title: [Activity] Decision Trees: Predicting Hiring Decisions

items.description: Random Forests was an example of ensemble learning; we'll cover over techniques for combining the results of many models to create a better result than any one could produce on its own.
items.title: Ensemble Learning

items.description: XGBoost is perhaps the most powerful machine learning algorithm today, and it's really easy to use. We'll cover how it works, how to tune it, and run an example on the Iris data set showing how powerful XGBoost is.
items.title: [Activity] XGBoost

items.description: Support Vector Machines are an advanced technique for classifying data that has multiple features. It treats those features as dimensions, and partitions this higher-dimensional space using "support vectors."
items.title: Support Vector Machines (SVM) Overview

items.description: We'll use scikit-learn to easily classify people using a C-Support Vector Classifier.
items.title: [Activity] Using SVM to cluster people using scikit-learn

items.description: One way to recommend items is to look for other people similar to you based on their behavior, and recommend stuff they liked that you haven't seen yet.
items.title: User-Based Collaborative Filtering

items.description: The shortcomings of user-based collaborative filtering can be solved by flipping it on its head, and instead looking at relationships between items instead of relationships between people.
items.title: Item-Based Collaborative Filtering

items.description: We'll use the real-world MovieLens data set of movie ratings to take a first crack at finding movies that are similar to each other, which is the first step in item-based collaborative filtering.
items.title: [Activity] Finding Movie Similarities using Cosine Similarity

items.description: Our initial results for movies similar to Star Wars weren't very good. Let's figure out why, and fix it.
items.title: [Activity] Improving the Results of Movie Similarities

items.description: We'll implement a complete item-based collaborative filtering system that uses real-world movie ratings data to recommend movies to any user.
items.title: [Activity] Making Movie Recommendations with Item-Based Collaborative Filtering

items.description: As a student exercise, try some of my ideas - or some ideas of your own - to make the results of our item-based collaborative filter even better.
items.title: [Exercise] Improve the recommender's results

items.description: KNN is a very simple supervised machine learning technique; we'll quickly cover the concept here.
items.title: K-Nearest-Neighbors: Concepts

items.description: We'll use the simple KNN technique and apply it to a more complicated problem: finding the most similar movies to a given movie just given its genre and rating information, and then using those "nearest neighbors" to predict the movie's rating.
items.title: [Activity] Using KNN to predict a rating for a movie

items.description: Data that includes many features or many different vectors can be thought of as having many dimensions. Often it's useful to reduce those dimensions down to something more easily visualized, for compression, or to just distill the most important information from a data set (that is, information that contributes the most to the data's variance.) Principal Component Analysis and Singular Value Decomposition do that.
items.title: Dimensionality Reduction; Principal Component Analysis (PCA)

items.description: We'll use sckikit-learn's built-in PCA system to reduce the 4-dimensions Iris data set down to 2 dimensions, while still preserving most of its variance.
items.title: [Activity] PCA Example with the Iris data set

items.description: Cloud-based data storage and analysis systems like Hadoop, Hive, Spark, and MapReduce are turning the field of data warehousing on its head. Instead of extracting, transforming, and then loading data into a data warehouse, the transformation step is now more efficiently done using a cluster after it's already been loaded. With computing and storage resources so cheap, this new approach now makes sense.
items.title: Data Warehousing Overview: ETL and ELT

items.description: We'll describe the concept of reinforcement learning - including Markov Decision Processes, Q-Learning, and Dynamic Programming - all using a simple example of developing an intelligent Pac-Man.
items.title: Reinforcement Learning

items.description: What's a confusion matrix, and how do I read it?
items.title: Understanding a Confusion Matrix
Measuring Classifiers (Precision, Recall, F1, ROC, AUC)

sections.title: More Data Mining and Machine Learning Techniques

items.description: Bias and Variance both contribute to overall error; understand these components of error and how they relate to each other.
items.title: Bias/Variance Tradeoff

items.description: We'll introduce the concept of K-Fold Cross-Validation to make train/test even more robust, and apply it to a real model.
items.title: [Activity] K-Fold Cross-Validation to avoid overfitting

items.description: Cleaning your raw input data is often the most important, and time-consuming, part of your job as a data scientist!
items.title: Data Cleaning and Normalization

items.description: In this example, we'll try to find the top-viewed web pages on a web site - and see how much data pollution makes that into a very difficult task!
items.title: [Activity] Cleaning web log data

items.description: A brief reminder: some models require input data to be normalized, or within the same range, of each other. Always read the documentation on the techniques you are using.
items.title: Normalizing numerical data

items.description: A review of how outliers can affect your results, and how to identify and deal with them in a principled manner.
items.title: [Activity] Detecting outliers
Feature Engineering and the Curse of Dimensionality
Handling Unbalanced Data: Oversampling, Undersampling, and SMOTE
Binning, Transforming, Encoding,  Scaling, and Shuffling
Spark installation notes for MacOS and Linux users

items.description: We'll present an overview of the steps needed to install Apache Spark on your desktop in standalone mode, and get started by getting a Java Development Kit installed on your system.
items.title: [Activity] Installing Spark - Part 1

items.description: We'll install Spark itself, along with all the associated environment variables and ancillary files and settings needed for it to function properly.
items.title: [Activity] Installing Spark - Part 2

items.description: A high-level overview of Apache Spark, what it is, and how it works.
items.title: Spark Introduction

items.description: We'll go in more depth on the core of Spark - the RDD object, and what you can do with it.
items.title: Spark and the Resilient Distributed Dataset (RDD)

items.description: A quick overview of MLLib's capabilities, and the new data types it introduces to Spark.
items.title: Introducing MLLib

items.description: We'll walk through an example of coding up and running a decision tree using Apache Spark's MLLib! In this exercise, we try to predict if a job candidate will be hired based on their work and educational history, using a decision tree that can be distributed across an entire cluster with Spark.
items.title: Introduction to Decision Trees in Spark

items.description: We'll take the same example of clustering people by age and income from our earlier K-Means lecture - but solve it in Spark!
items.title: [Activity] K-Means Clustering in Spark

items.description: We'll introduce the concept of TF-IDF (Term Frequency / Inverse Document Frequency) and how it applies to search problems, in preparation for using it with MLLib.
items.title: TF / IDF

items.description: Let's use TF-IDF, Spark, and MLLib to create a rudimentary search engine for real Wikipedia pages!
items.title: [Activity] Searching Wikipedia with Spark

items.description: Spark 2.0 introduced a new API for MLLib based on DataFrame objects; we'll look at an example of using this to create and use a linear regression model.
items.title: [Activity] Using the Spark DataFrame API for MLLib

sections.title: Apache Spark: Machine Learning on Big Data

items.description: High-level thoughts on various ways to deploy your trained models to production systems including apps and websites.
items.title: Deploying Models to Real-Time Systems

items.description: Running controlled experiments on your website usually involves a technique called the A/B test. We'll learn how they work.
items.title: A/B Testing Concepts

items.description: How to determine significance of an A/B tests results, and measure the probability of the results being just from random chance, using T-Tests, the T-statistic, and the P-value.
items.title: T-Tests and P-Values

items.description: We'll fabricate A/B test data from several scenarios, and measure the T-statistic and P-Value for each using Python.
items.title: [Activity] Hands-on With T-Tests

items.description: Some A/B tests just don't affect customer behavior one way or another. How do you know how long to let an experiment run for before giving up?
items.title: Determining How Long to Run an Experiment

items.description: There are many limitations associated with running short-term A/B tests - novelty effects, seasonal effects, and more can lead you to the wrong decisions. We'll discuss the forces that may result in misleading A/B test results so you can watch out for them.
items.title: A/B Test Gotchas

sections.title: Experimental Design / ML in the Real World

items.description: If you skipped ahead, I'll show you where to get the course materials for just this section. And we'll cover some pre-requisite concepts for understanding how neural networks operate: gradient descent, autodiff, and softmax.
items.title: Deep Learning Pre-Requisites

items.description: We'll cover the evolution of artificial neural networks from 1943 to modern-day architectures, which is a great way to understand how they work.
items.title: The History of Artificial Neural Networks

items.description: Google's Tensorflow Playground lets you experiment with deep neural networks and understand them - without writing a line of code!
items.title: [Activity] Deep Learning in the Tensorflow Playground

items.description: Let's dive into the details on how modern multi-level perceptrons are trained and tuned.
items.title: Deep Learning Details

items.description: We'll cover Google's open-source Tensorflow Python library, and see how it can help you create and train neural networks.
items.title: Introducing Tensorflow

items.description: We'll use Tensorflow to create a neural network that classifies handwritten numerals from the MNIST data set. Part 1 of 2.
items.title: [Activity] Using Tensorflow, Part 1

items.description: We'll use Tensorflow to create a neural network that classifies handwritten numerals from the MNIST data set. Part 2 of 2.
items.title: [Activity] Using Tensorflow, Part 2

items.description: The Tensorflow 1.9 offers a higher-level API called Keras, and makes it easier to construct your neural networks. We'll use Keras to solve the same handwriting recognition problem - but with much less code.
items.title: [Activity] Introducing Keras

items.description: As another hands-on example, we'll use Keras to build a neural network that learns how to determine if a politician is Republican on Democrat just based on their votes.
items.title: [Activity] Using Keras to Predict Political Affiliations

items.description: CNN's mimic your visual cortex, and can find features in one, two, or three-dimensional data even if you're not sure where exactly that feature is.
items.title: Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN's)

items.description: CNN's are better suited to image data, and we'll prove that by using a CNN in Keras on the MNIST data.
items.title: [Activity] Using CNN's for handwriting recognition

items.description: RNN's can handle sequences of data, like events over time or words in a sentence. Learn what's different about how they work, how they are trained, and ways to optimize them.
items.title: Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN's)

items.description: Let's implement a RNN in Keras to determine positive or negative sentiments for real movie reviews from IMDb!
items.title: [Activity] Using a RNN for sentiment analysis

items.description: We'll see how transfer learning makes it trivially easy to use pre-trained models for common AI tasks.
items.title: [Activity] Transfer Learning
Tuning Neural Networks: Learning Rate and Batch Size Hyperparameters
Deep Learning Regularization with Dropout and Early Stopping

items.description: As with any new technology, sometimes we can become overzealous in how we use it. A few cautionary tales to make sure your deep learning work does more good than harm.
items.title: The Ethics of Deep Learning

items.description: We'll show how Variational Auto-Encoders (VAE's) pair and encoder and a decoder in a neural network to create latent vectors that can be used to reconstruct synthetic images in an artificial neural network.
items.title: Variational Auto-Encoders (VAE's) - how they work

items.description: We'll walk through a Jupyter Notebook illustrating a Variational Auto-Encoder trained on the Fashion MNIST data set. When done, we will generate synthetic images of articles of clothing, and see how VAE's can also be used for unsupervised learning.
items.title: Variational Auto-Encoders (VAE) - Hands-on with Fashion MNIST

items.description: We'll learn how Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN's) pair an encoder fed random data with a discriminator that it fights against. This type of network can be used to generate random synthetic images of faces, synthetic music, synthetic data sets... whatever you can dream up. And yes, it's the tech behind "deepfakes" and all those viral face-swapping and aging apps.
items.title: Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN's) - How they work

items.description: To get a better feel of how GAN's are trained, we'll watch a simple model of 2D points learn over time, train a GAN to create synthetic handwritten numbers, and make a synthetic painting using AI and GAN's.
items.title: Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN's) - Playing with some demos

items.description: We'll dive into an actual notebook you can run and experiment with, that trains a GAN to fabricate synthetic random images of clothing!

details.description:
New!Â Updated with extra content on generative models:Â variational auto-encoders (VAE's) and generative adversarial models (GAN's)

Machine Learning and artificial intelligence (AI)Â is everywhere; if you want to know how companies like Google, Amazon, and evenÂ Udemy extract meaning and insights from massive data sets, this data science course will give you the fundamentals you need. Data Scientists enjoy one of the top-paying jobs, with an average salary of $120,000 according to Glassdoor and Indeed. That's just the average! And it's not just about money - it's interesting work too!

If you've got some programming or scripting experience, this course will teach you the techniques used by real data scientists and machine learning practitionersÂ in the tech industry - and prepare you for a move into this hot career path. This comprehensive machine learning tutorial includes over 100Â lectures spanning 15Â hours of video, and most topics include hands-on Python code examples you can use for reference and for practice. Iâ€™ll draw on my 9 years of experience at Amazon and IMDb to guide you through what matters, and what doesnâ€™t.

Each concept is introduced in plain English, avoiding confusing mathematical notation and jargon. Itâ€™s then demonstrated using Python code you can experiment with and build upon, along with notes you can keep for future reference.Â You won't find academic, deeply mathematical coverage of these algorithms in this course - the focus is on practical understanding and application of them. At the end, you'll be given a final project to apply what you've learned!


The topics in this course come from an analysis of real requirements in data scientist job listings from the biggest tech employers. We'll cover the A-Z of machine learning, AI, and data mining techniques real employers are looking for, including:




Deep Learning / Neural Networks (MLP's, CNN's, RNN's) with TensorFlow and Keras

Creating synthetic images with Variational Auto-Encoders (VAE's) and Generative Adversarial Networks (GAN's)

Data Visualization in Python with MatPlotLib and Seaborn

Transfer Learning

Sentiment analysis

Image recognition and classification

Regression analysis

K-Means Clustering

Principal Component Analysis

Train/Test and cross validation

Bayesian Methods

Decision Trees and Random Forests

Multiple Regression

Multi-Level Models

Support Vector Machines

Reinforcement Learning

Collaborative Filtering

K-Nearest Neighbor

Bias/Variance Tradeoff

Ensemble Learning

Term Frequency / Inverse Document Frequency

Experimental Design and A/B Tests

Feature Engineering

Hyperparameter Tuning


...and much more! There's also an entire section on machine learning with Apache Spark, which lets you scale up these techniques to "big data" analyzed on a computing cluster.

If you're new to Python, don't worry - the course starts with a crash course. If you've done some programming before, you should pick it up quickly. This course shows you how to get set up on Microsoft Windows-based PC's, Linux desktops, and Macs.

If youâ€™re a programmer looking to switch into an exciting new career track, or a data analyst looking to make the transition into the tech industry â€“ this course will teach you the basic techniques used by real-world industry data scientists. These are topics any successful technologist absolutely needs to know about, so what are you waiting for?Â Enroll now!




"I started doing your course... Eventually I got interested and never thought that I will be working for corporate before a friend offered me this job. I am learning a lot which was impossible to learn in academia and enjoying it thoroughly. To me, your course is the one that helped me understand how to work with corporate problems. How to think to be a success in corporate AI research. I find you the most impressive instructor in ML, simple yet convincing." - Kanad Basu, PhD
details.for_who:
Software developers or programmers who want to transition into the lucrative data science and machine learning career path will learn a lot from this course.
Technologists curious about how deep learning really works
Data analysts in the finance or other non-tech industries who want to transition into the tech industry can use this course to learn how to analyze data using code instead of tools. But, you'll need some prior experience in coding or scripting to be successful.
If you have no prior coding or scripting experience, you should NOT take this course - yet. Go take an introductory Python course first.

details.description:
This course will get you started in building your FIRST artificial neural network using deep learning techniques. Following my previous course on logistic regression, we take this basic building block, and build full-on non-linear neural networks right out of the gate using Python and Numpy. All the materials for this course are FREE.

We extend the previous binary classification model to multipleÂ classes using the softmax function, and we derive the very important training method called "backpropagation" using first principles. I show you how to code backpropagation in Numpy, first "the slow way", and then "the fast way" using Numpy features.

Next, we implement a neural network using Google's new TensorFlow library.

You should take this course if you are interested in starting your journey toward becoming a master at deep learning, or if you are interested in machine learning and data science in general. We go beyond basic models like logistic regression and linear regression and I show you something that automatically learns features.

This course provides you with many practical examples so that you can really see how deep learning can be used on anything. Throughout the course, we'll do a course project, which will show you how to predict user actions on a website given user data like whether or not that user is on a mobile device, the number of products they viewed, how long they stayed on your site, whether or not they are a returning visitor, and what time of day they visited.

Another project at the end of the course shows you how you can use deep learning for facial expression recognition. Imagine being able to predict someone's emotions just based on a picture!

After getting your feet wet with the fundamentals, I provide a brief overview of some of the newest developments in neural networks - slightly modified architectures and what they are used for.

NOTE:


If you already know about softmax and backpropagation, and you want to skip over the theory and speed things up using more advanced techniques along with GPU-optimization, check out my follow-up course on this topic, Data Science: Practical Deep Learning Concepts in Theano and TensorFlow.

I have other courses that cover more advanced topics, such asÂ Convolutional Neural Networks,Â Restricted Boltzmann Machines,Â Autoencoders, and more! But you want to be very comfortable with the material in this course before moving on to more advanced subjects.

This course focuses on "how to build and understand", not just "how to use". Anyone can learn to use an API in 15 minutes after reading some documentation. It's not about "remembering facts", it's aboutÂ "seeing for yourself" via experimentation. It will teach you how to visualize what's happening in the model internally. If you wantÂ moreÂ than just a superficial look at machine learning models, this course is for you.


"If you can't implement it, you don't understand it"

Or as the great physicist Richard Feynman said: "What I cannot create, I do not understand".

My courses are the ONLY courses where you will learn how to implement machine learning algorithms from scratch

Other courses will teach you how to plug in your data into a library, but do you really need help with 3 lines of code?

After doing the same thing with 10 datasets, you realize you didn't learn 10 things. You learned 1 thing, and just repeated the same 3 lines of code 10 times...




Suggested Prerequisites:

calculus (taking derivatives)

matrix arithmetic

probability

Python coding: if/else, loops, lists, dicts, sets

Numpy coding: matrix and vector operations, loading a CSV file

Be familiar with basic linear models such as linear regression and logistic regression




WHATÂ ORDERÂ SHOULDÂ IÂ TAKEÂ YOURÂ COURSESÂ IN?:

Check out the lecture "Machine Learning and AIÂ Prerequisite Roadmap" (available in the FAQ of any of my courses, including the free Numpy course)

details.description:
R Programming by doing!

There are lots of R courses and lectures out there. However, R has a very steep learning curve and students often get overwhelmed. This course is different!

This course is truly step-by-step. In every new tutorial we build on what had already learned and move one extra step forward.

After every video, you learn a new valuable concept that you can apply right away. And the best part is that you learn through live examples.

This training is packed with real-life analytical challenges which you will learn to solve. Some of these we will solve together, some you will have as homework exercises.

In summary, this course has been designed for all skill levels and even if you have no programming or statistical background you will be successful in this course!

I can't wait to see you in class,

What you will learn:

Learn how to use R Studio

Learn the core principles of programming

Learn how to create vectors in R

Learn how to create variables

Learn about integer, double, logical, character, and other types in R

Learn how to create a while() loop and a for() loop in R

Learn how to build and use matrices in R

Learn the matrix() function, learn rbind() and cbind()

Learn how to install packages in R

Sincerely,

Kirill Eremenko

details.description:
This course was completely redesigned in November of 2019 to match the demands and trends of the industry.

You already understand the basics of HTML and CSS, but you donâ€™t necessarily feel qualified for the web developer jobs you want. In this course weâ€™ll bridge that gap by building a mobile-first responsiveÂ website, together, step-by-step. Along the way weâ€™ll learn the modern skill-set that companies are looking for in developers.

I know what companies are looking for because as a senior developer Iâ€™ve been on the hiring side of job interviews. Every time we passed on a candidate Iâ€™d think to myself â€œIt would be nice if we could point them towards a course that taught the exact skill set weâ€™re looking for.â€

I couldnâ€™t find a course like that - so I built this one.

By the end of this course youâ€™ll be able to build sites using the modern skills, tools, and best-practices that companies need in developers.

Take your developer career to the next level by:

Learning Git, GitHub, and command-line basics to collaborate with other developers and deploy your sites live up onto the web.

Leveraging Node.js tools like NPM and webpack to save time by automating tasks.

Enhancing your CSS knowledge with techniques (BEM & PostCSS) to keep your styles super-organized and manageable even on larger sites.

Speeding up your sites with the mobile-first performance philosophy.

Understanding JavaScript basics like Object-oriented Programming, and how to write well-structured code using the ES6 module pattern (Babel & webpack).

Using the Netlify service to not only host your website but also learn the very basics of cloud (or AWSÂ Lambda)Â functions.

Discovering tips to get more job interviews, do well in interviews, and continually progress in your career (avoid burnout & stagnation).


This course may beÂ brand new, but this isnâ€™t my first time teaching. Iâ€™ve led trainings for Fortune 500 companies, and Iâ€™ve already helped over 7,000 people on Udemy andÂ received the following feedback:


"Brad definitely has some of the best techniques to embed the lesson into your mindâ€¦ hands down these are the best tutorials I have had the opportunity to view."


"Presentation is concise without being tediousâ€¦ you honestly feel that you have a thorough understanding of the subject."


"â€¦[Brad] explained the process. Not memorize this or that, he explained the process. If you're looking to take a course to understand the foundations of creating websites, look no further."


I've been teaching for the better part of a decade and IÂ consider this course my magnum opus. This is the course IÂ wish IÂ could have taken several years ago.

Become highlyÂ valuable and relevantÂ to theÂ companies that areÂ hiring webÂ developers;Â in one convenient placeÂ alongside one instructor. If you're ready to begin your transformation - I'll see you on the inside!
